Comment: Don't forget the impact this has on a very, very large number of small and home-based businesses.  Most of us relied on the de minimis exemption to order in supplies to make products for resale.  Many low income households rely on this income to get by.  I run a small lapidary business and because of the tariffs and the elimination of the exemption we are likely going to close once current stock is exhausted.  There's just no way we can absorb a 145% increase in costs.  Even if I tried to pass it on to my customers there's no market for the items at that price.  Who is going to pay it?  Before someone chimes in about buying American.  The products I need are not made in the US.  They are only produced in China and a lesser extent Thailand.  A good friend has run a home-based custom vinyl business producing t-shirts, totes, signs, etc for nearly 12 years.  It has supported her family through all sorts of hardships.  The cost of supplies is shyrocketing.  Wholesalers have already started raising prices. Her raising prices to compensate is only hurting sales.  She is on the verge of losing everything in a few months if something doesn't change.  These stories are being repeated all over Etsy, Amazon Handmade, and small Mom and Pop shops everywhere.  These changes aren't just making the "cheap stuff" on Temu, Shein, and AliExpress more expensive.  It's not just hurting Soccer Moms and Fashionistas.  It's hurting entrepreneurs, small business owners, and families.  ---  Just to drive the point home let me provide an example.  Yesterday, I looked at replacing some material I am almost out of.  Taking one as an example, 45g of it costs $15.00.  The wholesaler broke the cost out.  Item Cost: $15.00  Shipping: Free - For this example  Tax: .90 - I'll include it for the example  Other Fees (Tariffs): $21.75  Total: $37.64  So, a supply that used to cost me .35c per gram now costs me .84c per gram.  Doesn't seem like much on this scale, but multiply that kind of increase over and over again.  What business can absorb that kind of increase in costs?  Not many.
